cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Suez about April 6
R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about April 20.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Port Said April 9
R.M.S. "Orontes" will leave Port Said April 23
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday; 7th April, to be followed by S.S. Menes.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 11:30 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa until further notice the Sleeping Cars will be replaced, by a reserved first clas carriage in which a rug and pillow are supplied on payment of 10 P.T. which entitles thepassenger to one side of a first class compartment.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: PEACH'S LACE CURTAINS
div.p: A gift from England.
Lace Cover Free with illustrated price list. Import direct from the looma
Lace Curtains, Hosiery, Clothing, Furniture, Linens, Boots and Shoes, Carpets.
Popular Parcel 23/6 Carriage Free
Contains 5 pairs of Curtains, made especially for this Parcel, as follows:-
2 pairs alike Dining-room Curtains, choice desigh from Real Lace 3 1/2 yds. long, 60 ins. wide
1 pair superb Drawing-room Curtains, design from old Rose Point Lace, 4 yds long, 2 yds wide.
2 pairs alike Bedroom Curtains, 3yds, design from new style of modern art. Beru if desired. Customers throughout Empire testify to value and reliability. Send Post Office Order for 23/6.
The Parcel, well packed in Oilcloth, will be sent by post, direct to your address, by next Mail.
Colonials, save 50 per cent. and import your own goods, British made and reliable.
Lace Curtains, Laces, Blouses, Linens, Hosiery, Ladies' and Gents' Tailoring, Boots, Shoes, Gaiters.
Furniture Suites, Bedsteads, Carpets, etc. Prize Medals: Toronto 1892, Chicago 1893.
Apply at once for Price Lists at the office of this paper. If your wish the Gift included, send Direct to:-
Samuel, Peach & Sons, Manufacturers. Box 649, Nottingham, England. Est 1857.

div.head: IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT
div.p: Steam Ploughing,Cultivating, Level ling and Grading. Mea6rs. J. & H. McLAREN, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to announce to the'r friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principal, will be in Egypt for the month of March, 1906. He will be glad to make appointments with any interested parties to show them our steam plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam ploughs, and give most favourable prices for suitable Machinery.

He will aho show them our new Patient Gaeobeab, or veiling scoop, at work, which is thu most improved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has yt t bten put upon the marktt.
L and Proprietor, Agriculturists, and Contractor*, are requested to communicate with Mr McLAREN at Bhepheard's Hctil, Cai o, after March 1st, 1906.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.
S.S.-Subscriptions eemmeneses from the 1st to 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, ROWLAND WELLING, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. E.C.

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: WILLIAMSON.- At Kaer-el-Doubara, Cairo, on Friday, the 30th March, the wife of J.W. Williamson, of a son.

div.head: DEATHS.
div.p: PRESTINS- At Moharrem Bey, on the 30th inst., Alice Vivien Violettes, infant daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A.S. Preston, aged one day.
VACCARI.- At Alexandria, on the 30th March, Arbogasto Vaccari, in his sixty-second year.
The "Egyptian Gazette" is printed on paper manufactured and supplied by the London Paper Mills Co., Limited (sales office: 27, cannon street, E.C.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1890.
Editor and Manager – – R. Smelling
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.

div.head: ABYSSINIA.
div.p: A special telegram which we published in our last issue announced that an agitation had arisen in Abyssinia on the death of Ras Makonnen, the presumptive successor to the Emperor Menelik. But there is no apparent reason why the Emperor should not continue for many years to come to rule the destinies of the Empire which he has done so much to consolidate and extend. There are few more interesting figures in Africa at this moment than the Emperor has succeded in welding the subordinate kinngdoms under his rule into a fairly homogenous State, and in obtaining the recognition of its independence by the European Powers who are its immediate neighbours. But time is required to give permanency to his work and the problem with which the Emperor Menelik is faced is all the more difficult because there is no direct heir to his throne and that the presumed successor has just died. In these circumstances it is perhaps inevitable that there should be intriguing among the ambitious Rases, some of whom, it is believed, have not been disinclined to coquette with the representatives of the European Powers at Adis Abeba. But so long as Abyssinia remains united no single European Power could conquer the country; while it would prove a difficult and costly buisness for Great Britian, France and Italy combined to overcome the resistance which the Abyssinians could offer. But the real difficulty in Abyssinia is Germany, for it is rumoured that Kaiser's Moracco policy is to be repeated in that quarter of the world. It is currently reported on the Continent that he purposses to enter a siplomatic protest against the treaty now being arranged between the Negus on the one part, and the British, French and Italian Governments on the other. This compact does not infringe in the slightest degree on any German interests in Abyssinia, shadowy as they are; traders of that nationally will be as free to carry on commercial buisness as those of the signatory Powers. The main purpose of the arrangement is to shut out foreign politicial intrigue by a self-denying ordance between the three European Powers which have secured a solid footing in Menelik's domininons. For a considerable time he has been patiently but firmly striving for that object, and the treaty represents the outcome of his statemanship. Practically, it amounts to the neutralisation of Abyssinia, both politically and commercially, the guarentors being the three Powers most closely concerned in its peaceful development. It is absurd, therefore, for Germany to question their right to come to an agreement which, so far from injuring whatever trading interests the Kaiser imagines to exist, must benefit them in common with those of all other foreign nations.

div.head: ROSE'S LIME JUICE
div.p: Delicioius, Wholesome and Refreshing.
Prepared from the Choicest West Indian Lime Fruit.

div.head: German Despatch Boat.
div.p: The German despatch boat Loreloy left Alexandria this morning.

div.head: Standard Life Assurance Company.
div.p: The Hon. A. J. Davey has resigned his seat on the local board (if this ootnp&ny.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The Brindisi mail will close at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m on Sunday.

div.head: Locusts.
div.p: A flight of locusts passed over Helouan on Wednesday, going from north to south.

div.head: St. Mark's, Alexandria.
div.p: The anthem tomorrow at the 6.15 p.m. service will he "O Saviour of the World," by Goss.

div.head: Found Drowned.
div.p: The dead body of a native woman was found yesterday in the Mahmoudieh Canal, near Izbet Khorshid.

div.head: International Chamber of Commerce.
div.p: The annual general meeting of this Chamber will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, on Tuesday, April 10, at 5 p.m.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to March 29 amounted to 290, 267 tons, as compared to 152,182 tons during the same period last year.

div.head: Fire in Harbour.
div.p: A fire broke last night in hold No. 3 of the Canard liner Veria, in Alexandria harbour. The extent of the damage is as yet unknown.

div.head: New Cairo Newspaper.
div.p: A new Turkish newspaper has made its appearance at Cairo, entitled "Togron Sony" (The Word of Truth). It is an organ of the Young Turkey Party.

div.head: Pearl Fisheries.
div.p: A credit of L.E. 6,000 has been opened by the Sudan Government fnr the purpose of safeguarding the pearl fisheries. A. special fishery department is to be formed.

div.head: Sunday Closing.
div.p: The shoemakers' and drapers' establishments in Alexandria will be opened on the first and second Sundays of April, and will resume Sunday closing after Easter.

div.head: Penny Postage,
div.p: With effect from the 1st proximo, the postage on letters for St. Locia (Lesser Antilles) and St Vincent (B. W. I.) will be reduced and fixed at 5 millièmes for every 16 grammes or fraction thereof.

div.head: Egyptian Shells.
div.p: 170 packages of Egyptian shells were offered for sale in London last week at the second shell sales of the year. 0f these 100 were sold at rather lower rates. Small to bold 3l to 12s 6d ; pickings 1/ 12s 6d to 2/ 3s ; pieces 2l 12s 6d to 2115s.

div.head: Egyptian Ivory.
div.p: Up to data eleven tons and seventeen hundredweight of Egyptian ivory has arrived in London for the quarterly sales which will be held on April 24. The total quantity arrived in London of ivory of all sorts, including Egyptian, is twenty eight tons.

div.head: "The Sphinx."
div.p: We are asked to inform our readers that the last .number of the "Sphinx" for the present season will appear Tuesday next with a special illustrated supplement containing full accounts of the visit of their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Wales to Cairo.

div.head: Municipal Library.
div.p: The Municipal Library at Alexandria will be reopened to the public as from Monday next on the days and at the same hours as hitherto, viz., on Mondays, Tuesdays Wednesdays,Thursdays, and Saturdays from 9 a.m. to noon and from 4 to 7 p.m. On Fridays, Sundays, and holidays, it will be open from 10 a.m. to noon.

div.head: Army of Occupation.
div.p: As will have been noticed in our Army and Navy column yesterday, the Army Estimates fihow that provision has been made for the maintenance of 4,008 British troops in Egypt and Crete in the coming year, at a total cost of £312,770. The British troops last year, exclusive of the detachments in Crete, numbered 3 243.

div.head: Church of Scotland.
div.p: The Sacrament of the Lord's Sopper will be celebrated in St. Andrew's Church, Alexandria, at the close of divine service tomorrow morning. Visitors and friends cordially invited. Mr. Los. E Dutton's large and beautiful model of the Tabernacle of Israel will be exhibited in the church tomorrow evening at 6 o'olook. The explanation will be given by Mr. Float.

div.head: The St. James's.
div.p: All the man; patrnns of Shepheard's Hotel will be sorry that Mr. Richard Marbury is leaving the staff of the establishment. Mr. Marbury has taken the St. Jamea's Restaurant and on Monday next will inaugurate his acquisition of the property. We wish him every success in his new undertaking, for it would be difficult to find a more experienced and genial proprietor to preside over the well known Cairo restaurant.

BERLITZ SCHOOLS OF LANGUAGES 235 BRANCHES. French. German. Italian, Greek. Arabic, etc. Private Lessons. Residence Lessons, taught by Native Masters. ALEXANDRIA ; 20 Rue de i'Egliae Copte. CAIRO ; 1 Sharia Kamel. TRIAL LESSON FREE.

div.head: IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT. PREMIER CUTS UNHEROIC FIGURE.
div.p: The Press considers that the Premier cut an unheroic figure in the House of Commons yesterday in making an anject surrender to the Labour Party over the Trades Disputes Bill. This is not only discreditable to his statesman ship but, what is more important, it threatens to be a danger to the State.
Mr. Wyndhsm's scathing criticism of the Government marks a new era in his career.

div.head: COUNT WITTE'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: The influential papers of St. Petersburg publish reports of the impending resignation of Count Witte owing to ill-health, necessitating his retirement from public affairs.

div.head: THE PRINCES' LAWSUIT
div.p: Maitre Manneardi, of Cairo, is leaving for Italy on Thursday next in order to, discuss the bearings of the Khédivial Princes' ease with the Hon. Tommaso Vella, late Warden of the Seals and President of the Italian Chamber of Deputies, who has been briefed by the heirs of the Khedive Ismail.

div.head: UNIVERSITY OF ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Sheikh Mohamed Shaher, president of the Board of Ulema of Alexandria, informed a representative ot the "Gazette" in the course of an interview yesterday that the schenfe to found a religions university at Alexandria only took definite shape two months ago, although it had for some time past been a favourite project of his. The site most suitable tor the university is at Qabbari, near the Tekieh, now occupied by eshesbes erected by the Municipality, which has given the land to the Ulema Board.

The Khedive is much interested in the scheme, and it has also been favourably received by the Financial Adviser. The project will be submitted to the Council of Ministers. The name for the university will be chosen by the Khedive.

div.head: THE ULEMA STRIKE
div.p: The strike of the Ulema teachers of Alexandria still continues. They demand an increase of pay and have appealed to the Khedive and A1 Azhar No decision has been arrived at as to what is to be done in regard to satisfying their demands.

div.head: FRENCH POSTAL RATE TO EGYPT.
div.p: Picture postcards bearing written communications on the address Bide, in the part reserved for this purpose, are now by the French Government admitted to the ten-centimes rate for traffic with the French post-offices abroad, and also with Egypt, Haiti, and the Transvaal.

div.head: MALTEASE BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.
div.p: At the general meeting Of the members of this society the balance-sheet for last year was submitted and approved. Excellent work has been done by the committee in aid of the less fortunate class of their community. 49 persons were admitted to hospital and the society paid for 1,281 days' treatment, besides 778 medical visits during the year, with 22 operations. The committee districted 6.441 loaves and provided 925 persons with free medicine. House rent for 58 months was paid for those of their compatriots who wére in a very indigent condition and free passage home provided to the incurable. The society also contributed towards the upkeep of the Maltese Viotoria School, a free school founded by ihe Maltese community in commemoration of Queen Viotoria a Diamond Jubilee.

The committee for the ensuing year was elected as follows :—Mr. Leandro Camilleri, president ; Mr. Roberto Stabile, vice-president ; Mr. A. Cilia, treasurer ; Mr. A. Caruana Nani, secretary ; Mr. G. Podesta, accountant ; Mr. C. Aquilina and Mr. Alberto Cumbo, auditors ; and Messers A. Eajada, C. Buhagiar Borg. A. They, and G. Morello, members.
Mr. Mario Voila, who has been president of the society for five yeats, did not offer himself for re-election.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: PRINCE PRESENTS COLOURS TO THE INNISKILLINGS.
A PLEASANT CEREMONY.

The barrack square at Kasr el Nil pre aented a very animated see e yesterday afternoon on the oooasion of the presentation of new colours to the 2nd Royal InniskilliDg Fusiliers by H.R.H. the Priooe of Wales. The bandstand had been decorated with bunting for the occasion and the'galleries around the square were foil of spectators. Special invitations had been issned to the following gnests by Col. Cox, command:ng the 2nd Battalion of the distingui-hçd Irish regiment which received so signal an honour from the Heir Apparent : the Earl and Chnntess of Cromer, the Earl and Countess of Shaftesbnry, Mr. Frank and Lady Eva Dngdale, Lt.-Col. Sir Arthnr Bigge, Commander Sir Charles Cost, the Hon. Derek Keppel and M'g. Keppel, Commander Godfrey Fansaett, Mr. H. Montgomery, the 8irdar and Lady Wingate,* Misa Danford, General, Mrs. and Miss Bollock, Major Hoskins, Major and Mrs. Knight. Capt and Mrs. Bailey, Major Peroy-Smith, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Mantel!, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Ludlow, Col. Magil), the Rev. B. J. and Mrs. Hardy, the Rev. E. Ryan, the Rev. W. 8. and Mrs. Jaffray, Lt. Col. and Mrs. Atkinson, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Duckett, Major Lawson, Major Pine- Coffin, Major and Mrs. Cave, Lt-Col. and Mrs. Markham, Major and Mrs. Oxley, Miss Gardiner, Lt-Col. Watson Pacha, Capt and Mrs. Qilleon, Miss Ferrard, Major and Mrs. Parsons, Co).and Mrs. Bird, Major and Mrs. Staok, Lient. R J. Collins, Lt.-Col. and Mrs. Bernard, Lt-Col. and Mrs. Matchett, the Commodore and officers of H.M.S. Renown, the Captain and officers of H.M.S. Minerva, Mr. and Mrs. Alban, Hon. Mr. and Mrs. Iddings, Miss Iddings, Co), and Mrs. MoCraoken, Mansfield Paoha, Mr. and Mrs. Rnmbold, Captand Mrs. Maclean, Mr. and Mrs. M. de C. Findlay. Lt-Col. and Mrs, Cox, Major and Mrs. Wilding, Capt and Mrs. Somerville, the oolonel and officers 1st K. R. Rifles, the colonel and officers 1st Royal Dnblm Fusiliers, the AHjutant- Qeneral-and officers Egyptian Army, Col. Todd, Major and Mrs. Mylrea, Cept. and Mrs. Duffus, Major and Mrs. Donegan, Rev. F. and Mrs. Anderson, Rev. Sydney and Mrs. Smith, Sir Walter Lawrence, and the Lady Mary Criohton.

On the arrival of the Prinoe and Prinoesa of Wales at 4.40 p.m, the oeremonial began After the battalion, which was formed in line facing the stand, had saluted the arrival of the Prinoe and Princeu, the old oolours, borne hy Lieutenants Ball and Loftus, were carried round the battalion to the strains of "Auld Lang Syne." Then c&me the presentation oeremony. The battalion firmed three aides of a square, the new oolours in their oases laid upon the drums, and the Rev. E Hardy, Senior Chaplain to the Forces in Egypt, read the servies.

The hymn "Brightly gleams our banner" was sung and the Lord's Prayer repeated aloud. The Prinoe and Prinoess, who had descended from the stand with Lord Cromer, the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, Watson Paoha. Mr. M. de C. Findlay and the officer commanding, stood facing the band. Thu colours were then unrolled and handed by the Prince of Wales to Lieate nants Jennings and Adams, who reoeived them on bended kree.
At the conolnsion of this part of the oere- mony H.R.H. the Prince of Wales addressed the regiment as follows :—

"Colonel Cox, officers, non-commissioned officers, and men of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers,-—I am very pleased to prêt eut these new colours to you here today, on my way borne from India. It was in that country that your battalion was first raised in 1858* where it saw most of its active service. These colours bear the nsmes of the campaigns and battles iu which the regiment has taken part. They are rightly venerated as the emblem of the gallant deeds of thosu who • erved and of those who have died for their country. I feel sure that the colours will te an incentive to all ranks to maintain the great traditions of the regiment and to add fresh honours to its records. In handing the oolours to you 1 am confident that they will be safe in your keeping."
To these kind wordsColonelCox replied:—

Yoor Royal Highness,— I only regret that a. very considerable part of the battalion I command is absent in Crete and Cyprus on dnty and is therefore, unfortunately, unable to hear yonr most gracious words. In their name, and in the name of the offioers and men of the battalion here pre lent, and, I may add, in the name ol the four Irish connties that form onr territorial district, I thaï k yonr Royal Highness most sinoerely for the great honour yon have done us this day, and for the gracious terms in which you have expressed your appreciation of the past services pf the regiment. I can assure your Royal Highness that every offioer and man "who is fortanate enough in the future to serve under these new oolours just consecrated to the service of our Sovereign and ouroonntry, will nse his utmost endeavours to maintain the good name which the lnnis- ki.ling Begiment has always borne, whether in peace or war,and thus oarry on onr glorious traditions of the past.

The 2nd R. Inniskilfing Fusillon were formerly one of thé E. India Company's European regiments and saw sorvice and won renown in every Indian campaign. Wlion in 1858 tho old company regime passed away the regiment was incorporated in the British Army and has added to its reputation in India and S. Africa.

On the close of the Colonel's speech the battalion formed into line and the new colours were carried round to the tune of the "British Grenadiers." The general salute to the colours and the Royal salats followed, and before the close of this ceremony his Royal Highness inspected the battalion, afterwards expressing himself highly pleased with its appearance. The following offioers of the battalion then had the honour of being presented to his Royal Highness by Col. Cox : –Major C. A. Wilding, Capt. Somerville, Capt. Evans (Adjt.), Capt Blachett, Capt. Mathers, and Lieutenants Adams, Jennings, Ball, Loftus, Doffiu, and Lient, and Qr. Master McDonnell. Mrs. Cox Mrs. Wilding, Mrs. Somerville, and Mrs. McDonnell also bad the honour of being presented to H.R.H. the Princess ofWales.

div.head: RECEPTION AT BRITISH AGENCY.
div.p: About 200 invitations have been issued for the reception to be held at H.B.M.'s Agency on Tuesday evening. Six of the Khédivial Princes, the Ministers, the whole of the Diplomatic Corps, Ghazi Mnkhtar Pacha and his son, Perik Mahmoud Mukhtar Pacha, the Advisers, members of the Caisse de la Dette, and the principal British officials have been invited.

div.head: BEDOUIN BERGASS.
div.p: Thu following is the programme of the Native and Bedonin horse, and camel races ("Bedouin Bergass"), to bo held at Ghezireh on Tuesday,3rd April, commenoimr at 3.30 p.m., under the patronage of T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales and H.H. the Khedive.

Steeplechase. For horses. The property of native landowners ia the districts of Bilbeis, Nawa, Ashmonn, Giza. Galionb and Toukh over whose lauds the Abbassieh hounds have hunted. Distance around the course, to be ridden by owners or their sous in native costumes and with native saddles and bridles. Prizes: – 1st 1000 P.T. 2nd 500 P.T. 3rd 300 P.T.

Flat Race. For horses. The property of Bedouins of reoognised tribes. Distance 1 } mile to be ridden by owners or theirrsons in Bedouin costumes and with Bedouin saddles and bridles. Prizes :—1st lfOO P.T. 2nd 500 P.T. 3rd 300 P.T.

Camel Race For camels (Hagins). The property of Bedouins of recognised tribes. Distance 4 miles to be ridden by owners or their sons in foil Bedonin costumes, saddles and tranpingp. Prizes 1st 1000 P.T. 2nd 500 P.T. 3rd 300 P.T.

Flat Race. For horses of native land owners. Conditions same as 1st Race. Distance 1 ½ mile. Prizes : - 1st 1000 P.T. 2nd 500 P.T. 3rd 300 P.T. Flat Rack. For horses. The property of Bedouins of recognised tribes. Distance round ths course to be ridden by owners or their sons in Bédouin costumes, saddles and hirdles. Prizes: – 1000 P.T. 2nd 500 P.T. 3rd 300 P.T. Bedodin "Bergass."—Bedouin Sports and Display of trick riding and dancing horses.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: At the Mixed Tribunals, Cairo, this morning, Maitre Carton de Wiart stated that all the creditors bad approved of the following appointments, and which after due consideration the Court decided to confirm :—

Maitre Horftbitns was appointed as syndio, also M. Roux de Vance, manager of the Hawamdish factory. These gentlemen are to act together with Prot. Sampaolo, who has already been appointed by the Conrt,and under the supervision of Huari Paoha. Mr. Mo- Langhlin. manager of the Ottoman Bank at Cairo and M. Millet, delegate of the Banque d'Union Parisienne.

Discussing the absence of business on the Paris Bourse, the correspondent of a London financial contemporary remarks : The only fluctuation, for which a good reason exists, is that of the shares of the Egyptian Sngar Refineries. They are now worth about 8f. or 9f., if a buyer can he found, Since the Court of Appeal has cot firmed the bankrupcy ordered a fortnight ago by the Tribnruri of Commerce. The interested groups, shareholders' and banks holding Cronier bills, will now endeavour to induce tha Official Receiver to accept the concordat; which the coarts have rejected. On the other band, it is becoming more and more certain (a report which I mentioned weeks ago) that Sir Ernest Cassel and his friends will refloat the unfortunate concern, around which so many Egyptian, in addition to French and English, interests are centred.

div.head: SOLDIERS AND SAILORS' FAEILIES ASSOCIATION.
div.p: At a committee meeting of the above association it was decided to raise a fund to provide a district nurse for the Alexandrian locality, to attend such cases of illness in the soldiers and sailors' families ss are unsuitable for treatment in hospital. The subscriptions received in 1905, which may be taken as an average year, amounted tu £22.0-7 ½ d. It the present scheme is carried into effeot it will necessitate an extra annual expenditure of £100 or £120. Thus in order to maintain a nurse and carry on the ordinary relief-work of the association, a yearly income of nearly £160 will be required. It is proposed to apply to the head office of the Association in London for an annnal monetary grant, and to raise the remainder of the sum looally. For this purpose subscriptions or donations will be thankfnlly received. Cheques may be made payable to the Hon. Treasurer, Alexandria Branob, S.S. F.A., and all communications rhould be sent to him addressed British Headquarters, Alexandria.

div.head:
ROUGH WEATHER IN CANAL.
ALL SHIPS OBLIGED TO TIE UP.
div.p: Last night Port Said streets were quite deserted. All day it had been exceptionally hot and damp ; in fact, it was by far the worst day we have had this year. In the evening the wind sprang up and long before midnight it was blowing a gale. All the ships in the Casai, 17 in number, were obliged to tie up, being unable to proceed. Bad weather is also reported from outside, several Ships being overdue. There has been a steady wind blowing all day, and early this evening it started to rain heavily, with the result that the whole town ia nearly under water. It is a wonder that some steps are not taken to put things In a somewhat more satisfactory state, as the present system of drainage, if there is any, is a disgrace to the town.

div.head: TRAFFIC STOPPED IN CANAL.
div.p: The S.S. Mandalay went ashore in the Canal last night. She had several passengers on board. Togs were at once Sent to her assistance but ware unable to get her off, and on their return to Port Said it was found necessary to send more tags with fighters down, and they started to discharge the cargo immediately. Finally she was refloated at midnight after having discharged most of her cargo. Traffic has been stopped all day.

div.head: THE DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: The D. O. A. Prinzregent entered the Canal (Suez and) at midday to day with the Duke and Duchess of Connaught on beard, and had to tie up owning to the Mandalay being ashore. The Priozregent will not make a long stay at Port Said, and the Duke will probably not come ashore here.

div.head: LAST OF THE CHATHAM.
div.p: This afternoon the Canal Company blew up the remainder of the old S.S. Chatham. They bad been prepared for this final explosion for some time, and had been waiting for a favourable chanoe, which arrived this afternoon when traffio was stopped through the Mandalay being ashore. The explosion has been satisfactory, and the only reminder of the fatal spot where the Chatham went ashore is the large hole in the Canal bank.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA TRAMWAY CO.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has under consideration a scheme for the employment of motor omnibuses in Alexandria an its suburbs in connection with the tramway system of the Alexandria Tramway Company. The Alexandria Municipality has alresdy informed the Tramway Company that it has no objection to the employment of motor omnibuses by the company.

The company, on receipt of the Ministry's approbation, will start motor omnibases with seating accommodation for twenty persons in each 'bus. The 'buses will be fitted with first and second-class accommidation end will run in connection with the company's network of tramways, thus affording an easy and rapid system of intercommunication with all parts of the city.

div.head: WHEAT IN THE SUDAN
div.p: Several Egyptian landowners who visited the Sudan this winter are of opinion, says the "Sudan Times," that the country is admirably saited for wheat growing. lt is maintained by one of them that the net profit on the yield of a feddan cannot fall below P.T. 200. This he says may be less than the profit realized from cotton, but it should be borne in mind that so long as the labour in the Sudan are limited only small a be placed nnder cotton cultivation. It is easier to teach the natives to grow wheat than cotton; besides, the first does not require so many hands as the latter. The yield per feddan of wheat should average five ardebs.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Avjiurd'hui A midi et demie)

LTnvestment gagne de jour en juur du tarrjrif).' Yoioi qu'on est acheteur à 1 1/2 et môme a 1 17/82. Cette reprise, qui n'est d'ail- lentra qa'à son débat, provient d'une plus juste appréciation de la valeur de ce titre.
Avec l'InvestmeDt, on a échangé beaucoup d'Agrioole, de Cassa di Scouto, de Delta Laud et de Trust. Ces derniers ont snbi nne réaotion par suite de ventes assez importantes de la spéculation.
Il y a eu m matin une petite demande en fou data ors Land Allotment qui reiteut au même prix.
Bu Corporation of Western Bgypt, il n'y a a pas de oours clairement établi. On inscrit 1 1/4, mais il est impossible dt faire aucun achat à ce prix.
La reste dn marché demeure à peu près stationnaire, dans le oalme ordinaire du samedi.

Les prévisions pour la semaine prochaine sont excellentes. En dépit des fêtes de Pâques qui détourneront un peu da marohé l'attention pubfique, on s'attend à une forte acosntoation de la hausse sur les valeurs solides, pour peu que les marchés européens encouragent ce mouvement.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Curzon is staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo.
The Earl and Countess of Meath are staying at Mena Honse Hotel.
Sir William and Lady Ewart, Misses Ewart, Mr. Ewart, and party bave returned from Upper Egypt and taken up their residence at Mena House Hotel.

A dinner was given by Rear-Admiral Sigsbee on board the oruiser Brooklyn yesterday evening, being one of a series given in return for the hospitality he and the offioers of the squadron have reoeived ashore. Among the guests were Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield, Mr. and Mrs. James Hewat, Judge and Miss Batchellor, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Peel, M. and Mme Girard, Mrs. Reiss, etc.

Among the passengers who left Alexandria yesterday by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal were Count and Connteas de Vanreal, Earon van Tbielman, Mrs. Carton de Wiart, Mrs. Hunter, Co, and Mrs.Cadreu, Mr. Edgar Soares, M. Hocb, Miss Sheppard, Col. Pitzherbert, Mr. and Mrs. WorthingtoD, Capt. Carey, etc.
Among the passengers who left for Constantinople by the Khédivial S.S. Ismailia were Connt and Conntesa Sierstorptf, Baroness Lan Mainchboffer and daughter, Mohsen Bey Fauzi, and M. Le Bargy.

Mr. Antonio de Beuednooi. Consol at Alexandria for the United States of'Mexloo, who has been seriously ill with gastrio fever, has left for Greece by the Russian steamer accompanied by his family and a physician. It is hoped that the change will restore Mr. Beneducci to his usual health.

Captain F.G. Poole. D.S.O., East Yorkshire Regiment, now serving with the Bgyptian Army, and who has just been promoted to his captaincy in the gallant Snappen, has had a varied career. A Kent man by birth, his fad has been foreign travel and he has seen a lot ol the world. He was gazetted to the East Yorks, from Sandhurst, in 1892, and from 1806 to 1698 he wae employed in the British Central Africa Protectorate, and shared in tha expeditions against Chilwa and Mpezeui (medal with clasp), saw further service io the troubles in North Rhodesia and was in China daring the Boxer troubles. During that very trying period he was iu the besieged Legations of Peking and commanded the volunteers of all nationalities which helped to hold the place. He was wounded during the defence of the Legations, and afterwards was a Staff Officer of the China Field Force, and combined the daties of Transport Officer with th it of interpreter, he being a very able Chinese soholar (mentioned in despatches, D. S O., medal with clasp). Captain Poole, who for the past three years has bean attached to the Khedive's army, has written a bit on foreign travel, and hs has the honour of being a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Sooiety.

We regret to annonnos the death, which took place yesterday from heart disease, of Mr. Arbogasto Vaccari. for twelve years iospector of the Alexandria branch of ths S.P.C.A. Deceased was formerly in the Coast Guard Administration, where he held the rank of Saghcolaghassi. The funeral will take place this afternoon at the Civil Cemetery, starting from deceased's house at 5 p.m.

row.cell: Pour les Feves, Orges, Bles, Lentilles, Mais et Oignons, la consommation locale n'est connue respectivement que les 31 Mars et 24 Novembre
N.B.– L'année pour les Blés et les Lentilles commence au 1er Avril, pour les Mais le 1er Décembre, pour les Oignons le 1er Mars.
